alert.note: Alert for Northern Outer Banks (North Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued September 30 at 4:11AM EDT until September 30 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City
info.description: ...BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH THIS EVENING... ...COASTAL FLOOD WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM SUNDAY MORNING THROUGH MONDAY AFTERNOON... * WHAT...For the Beach Hazards Statement, dangerous rip currents, large breaking waves expected, and strong longshore currents in the surf zone. For the Coastal Flood Watch, 2 to 4 feet of inundation above ground level possible in low- lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways. * WHERE...Northern Outer Banks. * WHEN...For the Beach Hazards Statement, through this evening. For the Coastal Flood Watch, from Sunday morning through Monday afternoon. * IMPACTS...Up to 2 to 4 feet of inundation above ground level is possible for some oceanfront properties and roadways resulting in a significant threat to life and property. In some areas, battering waves will cause additional damage to property. Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water. Dangerous shore break can throw a swimmer or surfer head first into the bottom causing neck and back injuries. Strong longshore currents will create dangerous swimming conditions. Time of high total tides are approximate to the nearest hour. Duck NC MLLW Categories - Minor 5.5 ft, Moderate 6.0 ft, Major 6.5 ft MHHW Categories - Minor 1.8 ft, Moderate 2.3 ft, Major 2.8 ft Total Total Departure Day/Time Tide Tide from Norm Waves Flood ft MLLW ft MHHW ft ft Impact -------- --------- --------- --------- ------- -------- 30/09 AM 6.0 2.3 1.4 5 Moderate 30/09 PM 5.8 2.1 1.8 5-6 Minor 01/09 AM 6.8 3.1 2.1 6-7 Major 01/10 PM 5.8 2.1 2.0 7 Minor 02/10 AM 6.6 2.9 2.1 7 Major 02/11 PM 5.3 1.6 1.8 6-7 None &&
info.instruction: If travel is required, allow extra time as some roads may be closed. Do not drive around barricades or through water of unknown depth. Take the necessary actions to protect flood-prone property. Life-threatening rip currents. If caught in a rip current, remain calm. Swim in a direction following the shoreline. If tired, float or tread water until out of the rip current. If unable to escape, face the shore and call or wave for help. Shore break occurs when waves break directly on the beach. It is extremely important to protect your head and neck whenever you are in breaking waves by keeping your hands in front of you at all times. Strong longshore currents can sweep swimmers and surfers into rip currents, piers, jetties and other hazardous areas. In many cases, the longshore current is strong enough to prevent swimmers from being able to keep their feet on the bottom making it difficult to return to shore.
